Data Definition Language: Commands like CREATE, ALTER, DROP, TRUNCATE.

What does the WHERE clause do?
Filters records based on specified conditions.

GROUP BY groups rows. HAVING filters the groups based on aggregate functions.
What is ORDER BY used for?
Sorts the result set of a query by one or more columns.
VARCHAR is variable length; CHAR is fixed length. VARCHAR saves space but adds overhead.
A numeric data type used to store exact fractional values (currency, percentages).

What is the NOT NULL constraint?
Ensures that a column cannot have a NULL value.
Returns the average value of a numeric column.
Returns the number of rows that match a specified criterion.

A query nested inside another query (e.g., in the WHERE, FROM, or SELECT clause).
A subquery that is executed once for each row processed by the outer query.
What is a Common Table Expression (CTE)?
A temporary, named result set defined within the execution scope of a single SELECT, INSERT, UPDATE, or DELETE statement (using WITH).
A virtual table based on the result-set of an SQL statement. Data is not stored, but calculated when queried.
A transaction must be treated as a single, indivisible unit of work: either all changes are made, or none are.
Once a transaction has been committed, it will remain committed even in the case of system failure.
Determines the physical order of data in a table; only one per table.
Does not change the physical order; contains the index keys and pointers to the data rows; multiple per table.
When should you AVOID indexing a column?
For small tables, columns with many NULLs, or columns that change frequently.
What is the purpose of DATETIME/TIMESTAMP?
To store date and time values. TIMESTAMP often tracks modification time automatically.
Returns the first non-NULL expression in a list of arguments.
Returns NULL if expression1 equals expression2; otherwise returns expression1.
What is a FULL OUTER JOIN?
Returns all rows from both tables, filling in NULLs where there is no match.
A regular join used to join a table with itself, typically used for hierarchical data.
What is the purpose of GRANT and REVOKE?
To manage user permissions (privileges) on database objects.
Sets a marker within a transaction to which you can later roll back.
A prepared SQL code block that can be saved and reused, improving performance and security.
A special type of stored procedure that automatically executes (fires) when an event occurs in the database.
Difference between UNION and UNION ALL?
UNION removes duplicates; UNION ALL includes all rows (faster).
Perform a calculation across a set of table rows that are somehow related to the current row (e.g., RANK, ROW_NUMBER).
Assigns a sequential integer rank to each row within its partition.
Assigns a rank within its partition, leaving gaps in the numbering sequence when there are ties.
A temporary name given to a table or a column in an SQL query to make it more readable.
The steps the database engine will take to execute a query, used for performance tuning.
The process of modifying a query to make it run more efficiently and quickly.
How does SQL differ from NoSQL?
SQL is relational (schema required); NoSQL is non-relational (flexible schema).
Binary Large Object, used to store large amounts of binary data, such as images or multimedia files.
Limits the value range that can be placed in a column.
How do you modify a table structure?
Functions that operate on a single input value and return a single output value (e.g., UCASE, LENGTH).
Functions that perform a calculation on a set of values and return a single summary value (e.g., SUM, COUNT).
A code injection technique used to attack data-driven applications, in which malicious SQL statements are inserted into an entry field.
Intentionally introducing redundancy into a database to improve query performance.
What is the result of using COUNT(DISTINCT column)?
Returns the number of unique, non-NULL values in the specified column.
How to add a new column to an existing table?
ALTER TABLE table_name ADD column_name datatype;
How to drop a column from an existing table?
ALTER TABLE table_name DROP COLUMN column_name;
Ensures that concurrent transactions do not interfere with each other's execution.
Defines the degree to which one transaction must be isolated from the data modifications made by other concurrent transactions.
An index created on two or more columns of a table.
An index that includes all the columns requested by a query, so the database doesn't need to look up the data row.
What is the purpose of the RENAME command?
Used to change the name of a table or a column.
Used in a WHERE clause to search for a specified pattern in a column.
What are the wildcards used with LIKE?
Percent sign (%) for any sequence of zero or more characters, underscore (_) for any single character.
Rotating rows into columns, typically involving aggregate functions.
Rotating columns into rows, often used to normalize wide datasets.
Assigns a rank within its partition without gaps in the ranking sequence for ties.
Accesses data from a previous row in the same result set without self-joining.
Accesses data from a subsequent row in the same result set without self-joining.
BETWEEN checks for a range; IN checks for specific values in a list.
Compares a value to any value in a list or result set of a subquery.
Compares a value to every value in a list or result set of a subquery.
A set of privileges that can be granted to users or other roles.
A collection of database objects (like tables, views, stored procedures) owned by a user.
Dividing a large table into smaller, more manageable pieces based on row values (e.g., by date).
What is the purpose of the COMMENT ON command?
Adds comments to a table, column, view, or other object metadata.
Used to convert one data type to another (e.g., string to integer).
A function created by the user to encapsulate logic and reuse it in SQL statements.
How do you manually start a transaction?
Using the BEGIN TRANSACTION or START TRANSACTION command.
How do you make changes permanent?
A short-lived table that exists only for the duration of a session or transaction.
A CTE that calls itself, primarily used for traversing hierarchical data (e.g., organizational charts).
What is the CASCADE option in DROP TABLE?
Automatically drops dependent objects (like views or constraints) when the table is dropped.
What is the IS NULL operator?
Tests for empty values in a column, as standard comparison operators cannot be used with NULL.
Removes leading and trailing space characters (or specified characters) from a string.
What is the purpose of LIKE vs REGEXP?
LIKE is for simple pattern matching. REGEXP (or RLIKE) supports more complex Regular Expressions.
When the physical storage of index pages is out of order, leading to slower data access.
Universally/Globally Unique Identifier, a 128-bit number used to uniquely identify information.
A table that has a Foreign Key relationship pointing to its own Primary Key.

A situation where a transaction re-executes a query and gets a different set of rows (phantom rows) due to another transaction inserting or deleting rows.
A cache of database connections maintained so that connections can be reused when future requests are made.
An alternative name for a database object, often used to hide the object's original location or complexity.
Provides a default value for a column when no value is specified during an INSERT.
When is the HAVING clause mandatory?
When you need to filter the result of an aggregate function (e.g., COUNT > 10).
Restricts the number of rows returned by the query (often paired with OFFSET).
The result of a CROSS JOIN, where every row from the first table is combined with every row from the second.
A measure of how unique the values in a column are (high selectivity is good for indexes).
What is an ENUM data type?
A string object whose value must be chosen from a list of permissible values.
Replaces a NULL value with a specified replacement value.
Divides the rows in an ordered partition into a specified number of groups.
When should you use ALL or ANY?
When comparing a single column value to a result set returned by a subquery.

What is the purpose of DISTINCT?
Eliminates duplicate rows from the result set of a SELECT statement.
How to simulate a RIGHT JOIN using a LEFT JOIN?
Swap the tables and use a LEFT JOIN.

NUMERIC stores exact values with defined precision and scale; INT is a whole number.
An operation that inserts rows into a table if they do not already exist, or updates them if they do (often using MERGE).
A Foreign Key action that automatically deletes child rows when the parent row is deleted.
How to change a column's data type?
ALTER TABLE table_name MODIFY/ALTER COLUMN column_name new_datatype;
A directive given to the query optimizer to influence the execution plan.
A transaction that modifies data on two or more separate network computer resources.

What is the purpose of SET OPERATIONS?
